I don't think writing all 162 versions of assertEquals is necessary, but I =
do think writing assertEquals for arrays of all primitive types (when expec=
ted and actual are arrays of the same type) is useful.  I put together an e=
xpansion for JUnit 3.8.1 that has these and also assertions for Collections=
 (ordered and unordered), Readers, and InputStreams.  I'd sure like to see =
the standard JUnit supply all of these.
=20
..David..
=20

________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of El=
liotte Harold
Sent: Tuesday, August 23, 2005 8:17 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Comparing arrays in JUnit 4


Using the new array compare method this test case fails:

     @Test public void testArrayCompare() {
         int[] a =3D {1, 2, 3};
         int[] b =3D {1, 2, 3};
         assertEquals(a, b);

     }

However this one succeeds:

     @Test public void testArrayCompare() {
         Object[] a =3D {1, 2, 3};
         Object[] b =3D {1, 2, 3};
         assertEquals(a, b);

     }

This is a compile time error:

     @Test public void testArrayCompare() {
         int[] a =3D {1, 2, 3};
         int[] b =3D {1, 2, 3};
         assertEquals((Object[]) a, (Object[]) b);

     }


This test case also fails:

     @Test public void testArrayCompare() {
         int[] a =3D {1, 2, 3};
         int[] b =3D {1, 2, 3};
         assertEquals((Object) a, (Object) b);

     }


Short of adding 162 different methods to compare each and every possible=
=20
combination of arrays (something I would not rule out but it certainly=20
wouldn't be my first choice) does anyone see a reasonable way to use=20
Java 5 autoboxing to allow arrays of primitive data types to be compared?

--=20
